title: How to Sew a Headband

steps.headline: Sketch or print out a paper template for your headband.
steps.description: Use a tape measure to figure out the circumference of your head if you want to make a headband template from scratch. Using a piece of paper, draw out the dimensions of your headband. Make sure that it’s wide enough for your liking, while still long enough to fit around the top of your head. If you’d prefer to use a premade template, try using this one: http://www.simplysewingmag.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Headband-template.pdf. This particular template fits most adult heads. For this style of headband, you’ll be using an elastic band to secure the material around your ears and the back of your head.

steps.headline: Trace and cut out 2 pieces of fabric and 2 pieces of iron interfacing.
steps.description: Sketch around your template with a pencil or fabric marker so you have the exact measurements for your headband. Draw out 2 headband pieces of both patterned and iron interfacing fabric, while tracing 1 headband piece on the white fabric. Cotton is the best fabric to use for this project. The iron interfacing helps provide more depth to your headband, while the white fabric serves as a base for the patterned side of the headband. If you’d like to have a more detailed plan in place, try sketching a 0.25 to 0.5 inches (0.64 to 1.27 cm) seam allowance along the edge of the fabric pieces using permanent marker. Make sure that you sketch on the reverse side of the fabric!

steps.headline: Iron the interface paper onto the backside of 1 of the patterned pieces.
steps.description: Line up the fabric pieces so that the iron interfacing is centered on the backside (or non-patterned side) of the patterned pieces. Turn your iron on and go over the interfacing paper in long, smooth strokes, continuing until the material is attached to the fabric. Look at the instructions on your iron interfacing material to see what temperature you should set your iron to.

steps.headline: Pin the edges of fabric together lengthwise.
steps.description: Take 5-10 pins and secure the patterned and white piece of fabric together. Make sure that the fabric pieces are facing inside out, so that the seams won’t be visible on the finished product. Try to space out the pins so that they’re at least 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) apart. If you sketched out the seam allowances on the backside of your fabric, these markings should now be facing outward.

steps.headline: Stitch the headband together lengthwise using a sewing machine.
steps.description: Use a basic stitch setting to sew your 2 pieces of fabric together. If possible, try lining the edge of the fabric up with the guide beneath the needle of your sewing machine. Keep the fabric steady as you stitch, and aim to make the line of stitches as straight as possible. Don’t worry about using a fancy stitch setting for this part. Any basic stitch will do.

steps.headline: Turn the fabric right side out and insert an elastic band into the unstitched ends.
steps.description: Use your fingers to pinch and tuck the edges of the fabric, slowly pulling and unrolling the fabric until the pattern-side of the fabric is visible. Once the headband is right side out, insert a 15 centimetres (5.9 in) piece of elastic into the short, unstitched ends of the headband. Pin the ends of the elastic band about 1 centimetre (0.39 in) into each end of the headband. The elastic band should only be about 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) wide.

steps.headline: Sew over the short ends to keep the elastic in place.
steps.description: Use your sewing machine to attach the elastic band to the headband with a short row of stitches. Remove each pin as you stitch. For extra security, add another row of stitches along the shorter edges of the headband, about 5 millimetres (0.20 in) from the edge of the fabric.

steps.headline: Cut out a long strip of fabric from a T-shirt.
steps.description: Use a fabric marker and a ruler to measure out a piece of fabric that’s 6 by 19.5 inches (15 by 50 cm). After marking the piece of fabric with a permanent marker, cut it out using a pair of scissors. If you’re making a headband for an adult, make sure that the fabric strip is 6 by 22 inches (15 by 56 cm). The measurements for this fabric strip include a 0.25 inches (0.64 cm) seam allowance on the long edge of the fabric. Since T-shirt material tends to be pretty stretchy, these measurements apply to most adults and children.

steps.headline: Fold the strip in half and pin the longer edge.
steps.description: Make the fabric strip more narrow by folding it in half lengthwise. As you go, take a few sewing pins to keep the edges connected and in place. For consistency, try keeping the pins around 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart from one another. Keep the seam allowance in mind as you pin the fabric.

steps.headline: Sew the long, pinned edge of the headband together.
steps.description: Use a sewing machine to stitch the longer edges of the headband together. Don’t worry if the stitches look uneven or if they aren’t exactly straight, since the headband is currently inside out. To make your stitches extra secure, consider sewing back and forth a few times on the last 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) of your fabric. If you’d prefer, you can also use a traditional needle and thread to sew the ends of the fabric strip together.

steps.headline: Turn the headband right side out.
steps.description: Use your fingers to pinch the fabric at the edges of the headband, working carefully to reverse the material. Continue down the headband, pulling and pinching the material as you go until the material is no longer inside out. Keep in mind that the shorter edges still aren’t sewn together yet.

steps.headline: Pin and stitch the short ends of the headband together.
steps.description: Take 2-3 pins and use them to secure the unstitched, shorter ends of the headband together. Use a sewing machine to attach the shorter ends of the headband together. As you stitch, make sure to remove the pins from the fabric.

steps.headline: Turn the headband right side out and try it on to test the fit.
steps.description:
Use your fingers to flip the fabric outwards. Make sure that the seams aren’t facing out before trying it on. If the headband seems a little too snug, try ripping the seams connecting the short end of the fabric and stitching them together with a slightly shorter seam allowance. When using a seam ripper, always start by tearing the seams at the edge of the fabric. If you’re making the headband for someone else, be sure to let them try it on at this point. Adding a Bow
If you want to add a bit of flair to your headband, try adding a bow using a 4 by 6 inches (10 by 15 cm) strip of fabric.
